title: In pop-up camera phones if the phone falls, while the camera is popped out, wouldn't the front camera break or get damaged? Are such phones successful? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suppose, if you dropped your phone just-so on the popped out camera, that camera might break. I know for a fact that if you dropped your phone just-so on any glass surface, there’s an excellent chance it’ll chip or shatter. That’s not a good reason to stop making phones with glass screens. It absolutely is an excellent reason to stop covering the rest of the phone with glass, and yet, we have all-glass phones.  OnePlus has a good solution to this: the phone senses a fall, and will retract the camera when it detects a fall. It’s of course possible to that it won’t fully retract before it hits the ground, but it sure couldn’t hurt. Unless you’re trying to shoot selfies while falling, I guess. I think the pop-up camera vulnerability is extremely trivial compared to all of the other smashy bits in a modern smartphone. I also contend that the chance of such a camera breaking is terribly small. One big reason is simple: this is the phone for people who have little-to-no use for a selfie camera.  And seriously, Apple… that ultra-tiny bit of screen to the left and right of that black hole chasm you call a “notch” isn’t fooling anyone. You don’t make an all-screen phone. At least when Essential did it, it was just a tiny, arguably tasteful notch. Once your notch is 75% or more of the screen, it’s not a notch anymore.  The last time I took an actual selfie was 2015 or so, and I used an Olympus OM-D E-M5 mark II with a 17mm f/1.8 lens… not a phone. Late last year, I did make a video conference call. That’s about it. I have very little use for a selfie camera. So if you can hide it away so it leaves me with an unbroken vista of a screen, great! Sign me up! If you’re a selfie-addict, this is probably not the phone for you. As soon as someone makes on without a glass back, with an interchangeable battery, and a microSD or UFS memory card slot, I’m there!

From what I have seen on several of the pop up type camera smartphones, the mechanism is a very robust item. They are designed for not failing so easily. If you like the feature or not the idea is a choice you would need to make. They are pretty successful and many who have them love them. I mean there is always the chance of a failure but then so is dropping your phone and shattering the screen. Every screen will break if it lands on the perfect spot. They are delicate devices, not Tonka Trucks.
